perturbation.original_text: (vi) the Agent represents and warrants that with respect to Offered Shares to be sold in reliance on Rule 506(b) of Regulation D, none of it, the U.S. Affiliate, any of its or the U.S. Affiliate's directors, executive officers, general partners, managing members or other officers participating in the Offering, or any other person associated with the Agent who will receive, directly or indirectly, remuneration for solicitation of Subscribers of Offered Shares pursuant to Rule 506(b) of Regulation D (each, a "Dealer Covered Person" and, together, "Dealer Covered Persons"), is subject to any Disqualification Event except for a Disqualification Event (i) covered by Rule 506(d)(2)(i) of Regulation D and (ii) a description of which has been furnished in writing to the Corporation prior to the date hereof;
perturbation.changed_text: (vi) the Agent represents and warrants that with respect to Offered Shares to be sold in reliance on Rule 506(b) of Regulation D, any of its or the U.S. Affiliate's directors, executive officers, general partners, managing members or other officers participating in the Offering, or any other person associated with the Agent who will receive, directly or indirectly, remuneration for solicitation of Subscribers of Offered Shares pursuant to Rule 506(b) of Regulation D (each, a "Dealer Covered Person" and, together, "Dealer Covered Persons"), may be subject to a Disqualification Event. Disclosure of such Disqualification Events is not required until 30 days after the closing date of the offering.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts Rule 506(e) of Regulation D, which requires issuers to exercise reasonable care to ensure that purchasers are not disqualified from purchasing securities. Delaying the disclosure of disqualification events until after the closing date eliminates the opportunity to assess and mitigate any potential risks to investors, which goes directly against the intentions of Rule 506.

perturbation.original_text: (vii) the Agent represents that it is not aware of any person (other than any Dealer Covered Person) that has been or will be paid (directly or indirectly) remuneration for solicitation of Subscribers in connection with the sale of any Offered Shares pursuant to Rule 506(b) of Regulation D; and
perturbation.changed_text: (vii) The Agent represents that it may become aware of persons (other than any Dealer Covered Person) that will be paid (directly or indirectly) remuneration for solicitation of Subscribers in connection with the sale of any Offered Shares pursuant to Rule 506(b) of Regulation D, without disclosing such information to the Corporation.
perturbation.explanation: This change contradicts the requirement for full and transparent disclosure regarding individuals receiving remuneration in connection with the sale of securities under Rule 506(b) of Regulation D. By allowing the agent to remain silent even if they become aware of undisclosed compensated individuals. This lack of disclosure could mask conflicts of interest and potentially expose investors to undisclosed risks.

perturbation.original_text: (viii) the offering of the Securities in the United States has been conducted by us in accordance with the terms of the Agency Agreement, including Schedule A attached hereto.
perturbation.changed_text: (viii) the offering of the Securities in the United States has been conducted by us largely in accordance with the terms of the Agency Agreement, but material deviations may occur without prior notice.
perturbation.explanation: This modification introduces ambiguity and directly undermines the compliance requirement stated in the original text. It implies that the offering may not fully adhere to the Agency Agreement, which directly contradicts the assurance that the offering is being conducted in accordance with its terms. This could also violate the Securities Act of 1933.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act of 1933 and Agency Agreement Terms
